item.title: Razer's New White Wolverine V3 Pro Controller Is $60 Off At Amazon, But Probably Not For Long
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/razers-new-white-wolverine-v3-pro-controller-is-60-off-at-amazon-but-probably-not-for-long/1100-6529237/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Razer launched a new white model of its Wolverine V3 Pro wireless controller for Xbox and PC today, and if you act fast, you can save 30% on the pro controller at Amazon. The discount drops the price from $200 to just $140 when you click the coupon code check box on its Amazon store page. This is a massive discount, especially for a newly released controller like this, but we're not sure how long the deal will be available, so grab it while you can. Note that the coupon appears to be region-based and may not be available to all customers.

The original black edition of the Wolverine V3 Pro released last August and has yet to receive a discount, so it seems likely that Amazon's deal on the new model is actually a pricing error.

Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Wireless Controller for Xbox & PC

$140 (was $200) with 30% off coupon

Specifications:

  • Includes hardshell carrying case
  • Wireless connection on Xbox & PC via 2.4GHz dongle
  • 10-foot braided USB-C cable for PC-only Tournament Mode
  • Microswitch face buttons and bumpers
  • 8-way "floating" microswitch D-pad
  • 6 remappable buttons (4 rear triggers, 2 shoulder buttons)
  • Adjustable trigger stops
  • Hall Effect thumbsticks with anti-friction rings
  • Swappable thumbstick caps (includes 4 sticks)
  • Custom profile support
  • Haptic feedback
  • RGB lighting
  • Razer Controller App features:
    • Create custom profiles
    • Adjust RGB lighting effects
    • Adjust stick & trigger sensitivity
    • Programmable multi-function settings button

Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Tournament Edition Wired Controller

$100

Specifications:

  • Wired-only connection (10-foot braided USB-C cable)
  • PC-only Tournament Mode features 1000Hz polling rate
  • Microswitch face buttons and bumpers
  • 8-way "floating" microswitch D-pad
  • 6 remappable buttons (4 rear triggers, 2 shoulder buttons)
  • Adjustable trigger stops
  • Hall Effect thumbsticks with anti-friction rings
  • Swappable thumbstick caps (includes 4 sticks)
  • Custom profile support
  • Haptic feedback
  • Razer Controller App features:
    • Create custom profiles
    • Adjust stick & trigger sensitivity
    • Programmable multi-function settings button

As you can see from the gamepad's specs, the Razer Wolverine V3 Pro is packed with pro-level features that make it one of our favorite pro controllers available for Xbox and PC. If you want to read more, be sure to check our Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Controller review for a deeper dive into the device's functionality and performance.

The Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Wireless Controller is also available in a $200 black model, but the 30% discount does not apply to this version, so you'll want to stick with the new white model if you're looking to save on a wireless model. Razer also launched a white variant of the wired Wolverine V3 Tournament Edition Controller that is available for $100.

  • Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Wireless Controller - White (Xbox, PC) -- $140 with coupon code ($200)
  • Razer Wolverine V3 Pro Wireless Controller - Black (Xbox, PC) -- $200
  • Razer Wolverine V3 Tournament Edition Wired Controller - White (Xbox, PC) -- $100
  • Razer Wolverine V3 Tournament Edition Wired Controller - Black (Xbox, PC) -- $100

This is one of the lowest prices you'll find on a high-quality Xbox Pro controller option--assuming the coupon is available to your region. Even the price of Xbox's first-party pro controller, the Elite Series 2, has climbed back up to $170, which nearly matches its $180 launch price. That said, if you'd prefer the Elite Series 2, you can grab the Elite Series 2 Core controller for $96 (normally $140), which is essentially the Elite Series 2 stripped of accessories. However, you can pair the Elite Series 2 Core controller with the Scuf Elite Series 2 Paddles and Thumbsticks for $20 each, and you'll have a pretty close substitute for the full Elite Series 2 that costs less than the real thing.

item.title: A Longtime Microsoft Exclusive Franchise Makes Its PlayStation Debut In March
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/a-longtime-microsoft-exclusive-franchise-makes-its-playstation-debut-in-march/1100-6529235/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Developer World's Edge has announced that Age of Mythology: Retold and Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition will be launching on PlayStation 5 this year.

The Age of Empires spin-off Age of Mythology: Retold is releasing on March 4 with the same content as the Xbox and PC versions, including the new expansion launching on the same day, the Chinese-themed Immortal Pillars. The PS5 version will also include cross-play and every future update will be pushed onto all platforms. The Premium Edition grants five-day early access starting on February 27 and preorders include two exclusive Blessings for the Arena of the Gods mode.

In Spring 2025, Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition will drop on PS5 alongside new DLC expansions for all platforms. While World's Edge didn't provide any additional details, the studio did show a sneak peek at of what's to come.

World's Edge also revealed that it's working on a second DLC expansion for Age of Empires IV, which is also going to launch this year. The first one, Knights of Cross and Rose, is set to launch in spring.

These games are the latest ones to make the jump over from Xbox to PlayStation after being console-exclusive to the former for years. Last week, Microsoft announced that Forza Horizon 5 would be coming to PS5 this spring.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Is Reportedly Bringing Back The Portal Platform From 2042
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/battlefield-6-is-reportedly-bringing-back-the-portal-platform-from-2042/1100-6529232/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The next installment of the Battlefield series--ostensibly Battlefield 6--is bringing back the acclaimed Battlefield Portal feature from the otherwise critically maligned Battlefield 2042, according to a YouTuber.

Content creator Flakfire said in a video uploaded Monday that he was invited to an online presentation detailing the Battlefield Labs community testing experience. Developers confirmed in the presentation that Portal, a custom-games-mode platform in 2042, is returning in the upcoming Battlefield game, Flakfire said.

In Battlefield 2042, Portal featured maps, weapons, and vehicles from previous titles in the franchise, namely Battlefield 1942, Battlefield: Bad Company 2, and Battlefield 3. While it is unknown what Portal could include in the next Battlefield game, Flakfire said developers told him that Portal could be one of the features that players test in the Battlefield Labs program.

At the time of 2042's initial release, publisher Electronic Arts called Battlefield Portal a "love letter" to the franchise's fans. While the feature provided players and reviewers with a rush of nostalgia at launch, fan reception to the mode became more lukewarm in recent years.

At least prospective players of Battlefield 6 may have the opportunity to have a say in what the next iteration of Battlefield Portal looks like if they sign up for Battlefield Labs. EA said that interest in the testing program has "exceeded [its] expectations" to the point where fans are running into issues with the sign-up queue page. EA said it is resolving the technical issues, and the first Battlefield Labs test sessions are due to begin "in the coming weeks."

item.title: MLB The Show 25 Limited Edition Is Up For Preorder, Includes Topps Baseball Card
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/mlb-the-show-25-limited-edition-is-up-for-preorder-includes-topps-baseball-card/1100-6529227/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

This year marks the 20th anniversary of MLB The Show, and to celebrate, MLB The Show 25 has three players on its cover for the first time--Pirates pitcher Paul Skenes, Reds shortstop Elly De La Cruz, and Orioles shortstop Gunnar Henderson. In addition to being cover athletes, each of these young stars is getting their own MLB The Show Topps Trading Card. MLB The Show fans and baseball card collectors can get one of the trading cards by preordering The Show 25's physical edition ahead of its March 18 release.

Unlike previous years, MLB The Show won't be available on Xbox Game Pass, so Xbox Series X players will need to buy a copy to play at launch. PlayStation says the game won't be on any subscription services in 2025.

Check out all of your MLB The Show 25's preorder options below. For more on the upcoming baseball sim, check out our story on the revamped Road to the Show mode.

MLB The Show 25 Limited Edition

$70

MLB The Show 25's Limited Edition costs the same price as the standard edition normally does--$70 for PS5 and Xbox Series X, $60 for Nintendo Switch--but it comes with five The Show card packs for Diamond Dynasty mode and a pretty enticing physical bonus.

While supplies last, the physical edition includes an exclusive MLB The Show Topps Trading Card featuring one of the three cover athletes: Skenes, De La Cruz, or Henderson. Once the batch of Limited Edition copies sells out--which very well could happen before launch--listings will likely convert to standard edition without the trading card bonus.

Only the PS5 edition is listed as "Limited Edition" at Best Buy and GameStop, but the cases for Nintendo Switch and Xbox Series X also show the trading card bonus, so the trading card should be available on all three console platforms.

You can preorder the Limited Edition at Best Buy, Target, and GameStop right now; we'll update this preorder guide once Amazon and Walmart unlocks preorders.

Unlike previous years, PlayStation is not producing a $100 edition with a baseball cap and steelbook case.

You can pick up a digital edition of the game as well, though you won’t get the Topps card. Instead, you’ll get the Gold Choice Pack preorder bonus. Both digital and physical versions also come with 5 The Show Packs.

MLB The Show 25 Digital Editions

You can pick up a digital edition of the game for $70 as well, though you won’t get the Topps card. Instead, you’ll get the Gold Choice Pack preorder bonus. Just like the physical edition, you'll get five The Show card packs.

Looking for tons of digital goodies for Diamond Dynasty? Consider checking out the $100 Digital Deluxe Edition to snag the following:

  • 4 days of early access
  • Double daily rewards
  • 20 Show Packs
  • 1 20th Anniversary Choice Pack
  • 1 Diamond Choice Pack
  • 5 Gold Choice Packs
  • 20K Stubs
  • 1 Equipment Pack
  • 1 Cover Athlete Bat Skin

item.title: Activision Raises $2.6 Million For Los Angeles Fire Relief Efforts Via Call of Duty DLC And More
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/activision-raises-2-6-million-for-los-angeles-fire-relief-efforts-via-call-of-duty-dlc-and-more/1100-6529230/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Activision has announced that it has raised more than $1.6 million for the Los Angeles fire relief efforts through the sale of the LA Fire Relief in-game DLC for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Warzone.

As announced previously, the funds are being donated to the Los Angeles Fire Department Foundation and Direct Relief. The $1.6 million is in addition to Activision's previous $1 million donation, which brings the company's total donation efforts to $2.6 million.

"Thank you to the Call of Duty community for their support, which will make a real impact for those who were affected by the LA fires," Activision said.

Thank you Call of Duty community. Players and fans around the world have come together to raise more than $1.6 million dollars through the purchase of the LA Fire Relief Pack.

These funds will go directly to the LAFD Foundation and Direct Relief for local fire relief and… pic.twitter.com/MGywT8d0nn

— Call of Duty (@CallofDuty) February 4, 2025

The LA Fire Relief DLC for Black Ops 6 and Warzone was priced at 2,400 COD Points, or about $20. This means Activision may have sold around 80,000 of the DLC packs. Activision has held previous donation efforts via in-game Call of Duty DLC packs supporting military veterans.

Multiple fires ripped through areas of Southern California in early January, torching thousands of structures and killing more than 25 people in what was California's biggest urban wildfire event in four decades. Experts believe fires like this in populated areas may increase in time.
